open_questions.title: The OSI model, and why is
open_questions.description: What is the OSI model, and why is it important in networking?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the OSI model, and why is it important in networking?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model is a conceptual framework used to understand how network protocols and communication work. It's important because it standardizes networking concepts into seven layers, making it easier to discuss and design networks. The layers are: Physical layer: Responsible for the physical connection between devices. Data Link layer: Responsible for creating a link between devices and error-free data transfer. Network layer: Responsible for routing data packets between devices. Transport layer: Responsible for the reliable delivery of data between devices. Session layer: Responsible for establishing, maintaining, and terminating communication sessions between devices. Presentation layer: Responsible for formatting and converting data for use by the application layer. Application layer: Responsible for providing an interface for applications to access the network.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between TCP and UDP.
open_questions.description: Explain the difference between TCP and UDP.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the difference between TCP and UDP.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is a connection-oriented protocol that ensures reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of data. UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is connectionless and provides faster but less reliable data transfer. UDP is commonly used in applications where speed is crucial, and data loss can be tolerated, such as video streaming and online gaming.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A network topology
open_questions.description: What is a network topology?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a network topology?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A network topology refers to the physical or logical layout of a computer network, including the arrangement of devices and the connections between them.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Name some common network topologies
open_questions.description: Name some common network topologies?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name some common network topologies?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Bus: In a bus topology, all devices are connected to a single central cable, called the bus. Data is transmitted along the bus and all devices receive it, but only the device for which the data is intended processes it. Star: In a star topology, each device is connected to a central hub or switch. Data is transmitted from the source device to the hub, which then forwards it to the intended destination device. Ring: In a ring topology, each device is connected to two other devices, creating a circular network. Data is transmitted around the ring in one direction and passes through each device until it reaches its destination. Mesh: In a mesh topology, each device has a direct connection to every other device in the network. This allows multiple paths for data to travel, making the network more robust and resistant to failure. Tree: In a tree topology, the network is connected in a hierarchical manner, with a root node connected to one or more intermediary nodes, which are in turn connected to leaf nodes. Hybrid: It's a combination of two or more topologies
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: A protocol is a set of rules and standards that govern the communication between devices in a network. It defines the format of the data being transmitted, as well as the procedures for establishing, maintaining, and ending communication between devices.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Name some common network protocols
open_questions.description: Name some common network protocols?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name some common network protocols?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Internet Protocol (IP): This is a network layer protocol that is responsible for routing data packets between devices on a network. Transmission Control Protocol (TCP): This is a transport layer protocol that is responsible for ensuring that data is delivered reliably and in the correct order between devices. Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP): This is an application layer protocol used for sending and receiving email messages. File Transfer Protocol (FTP): This is an application layer protocol used for transferring files between devices on a network. Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP): This is an application layer protocol used for transferring data over the World Wide Web. Secure Socket Layer (SSL) and Transport Layer Security (TLS): These are cryptographic protocols used to secure network communications.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of an IP address
open_questions.description: What is the purpose of an IP address and a MAC address?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the purpose of an IP address and a MAC address?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: An IP address (Internet Protocol address) is used for network layer routing and identifies a device on a network. It is necessary for devices to communicate across different networks. A MAC address (Media Access Control address) is used for data link layer communication within a local network (e.g., Ethernet). It is a unique hardware address assigned to network interfaces.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: A MAC address table (also known as a MAC address forwarding table) is used by network switches to map MAC addresses to physical switch ports. It helps the switch determine where to forward data frames based on destination MAC addresses.

open_questions.title: The subnet mask, and how does
open_questions.description: What is the subnet mask, and how does it relate to IP addressing?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the subnet mask, and how does it relate to IP addressing?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A subnet mask is used to divide an IP address into network and host portions. It determines which part of an IP address represents the network and which part represents the host. For example, in the IP address 192.168.1.10 with a subnet mask of 255.255.255.0, the first three octets (192.168.1) represent the network, and the last octet (10) represents the host.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: NAT is used to map private IP addresses within a local network to a single public IP address for outgoing internet traffic. It helps conserve public IP addresses and provides a level of security by hiding internal network structure from external networks.

referenceAnswers.text: DNS translates human-readable domain names (e.g., www.example.com) into IP addresses that computers can understand. It does this by maintaining a distributed database of domain names and their corresponding IP addresses. When you enter a URL in a web browser, DNS servers resolve it to the associated IP address, enabling the browser to fetch the web page.

Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Symmetric encryption uses the same key for both encryption and decryption, while asymmetric encryption uses a pair of public and private keys. Symmetric encryption is faster but requires secure key exchange. Asymmetric encryption is more secure for key exchange but is slower.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: DHCP is a network protocol used to automatically assign IP addresses and configuration settings (e.g., subnet mask, gateway) to devices on a network. DHCP servers lease IP addresses to devices for a specific duration. When a device joins a network, it can request an IP address and related settings from the DHCP server.

open_questions.title: Streams and datagrams
open_questions.description: What are streams and datagrams?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are streams and datagrams?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Streams: A stream is a continuous flow of data that is transmitted between devices as a sequence of bytes. The data is transmitted in the order it was generated and it is guaranteed to be delivered in that order. E.g. Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) Datagrams: A datagram is a self-contained packet of data that is transmitted between devices. Each datagram contains its own header information, which includes the destination address, and is treated as a separate unit of data. The User Datagram Protocol (UDP) uses a datagram-based approach to data transfer, where data is divided into packets, each of which is sent independently to the receiver. There is no guarantee that the packets will be delivered in the order they were sent, and it's up to the application to handle any out-of-order packets.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Amplitude modulation (AM): The amplitude (or strength) of the carrier signal is varied in proportion to the baseband signal. Frequency modulation (FM): The frequency of the carrier signal is varied in proportion to the baseband signal. Phase modulation (PM): The phase of the carrier signal is varied in proportion to the baseband signal.

Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Framing
open_questions.description: What is framing?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is framing?" referenceAnswers.text: Framing in networks refers to the process of dividing a stream of data into smaller, manageable units called frames before they are transmitted over a network. The frames are used to provide a structure for the data and to add control information, such as error detection and correction codes, that can be used to ensure the integrity of the data as it is transmitted. There are several types of framing techniques, including: bit stuffing and byte stuffing.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Error detection in networks refers to the process of identifying errors that occur in the transmission of data over a network. These errors can occur due to various reasons such as noise, interference, or hardware failure. Techniques include: Parity Checksum Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC)

open_questions.title: The differences between Parity, Checksum, and
open_questions.description: Explain the differences between Parity, Checksum, and Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC)?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the differences between Parity, Checksum, and Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC)?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Parity: A parity bit is added to each data unit (byte, word, etc.) to ensure that the number of 1's in the unit is even or odd. If an error occurs, the parity bit will no longer match the data unit, indicating that an error has occurred. Checksum: A checksum is a value calculated from the data in the packet. The sender and receiver both calculate the checksum of the packet, and if the values do not match, an error is assumed to have occurred. Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC): A more robust error detection method than parity and checksum. A polynomial division is performed on the data unit with a pre-agreed upon divisor and the remainder is appended to the data unit to form the code word. The receiver performs the same polynomial division and if the remainder is not zero, an error is assumed to have occurred.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: BGP route aggregation involves summarizing multiple IP prefixes into a single, more specific prefix to reduce the size of BGP routing tables. It helps improve routing table scalability and reduces the memory and processing overhead on routers.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Answer directly: JS is executed by an engine that compiles/JITs internally; Explain interpreted vs compiled as a spectrum in modern engines; Mention parse -> bytecode -> JIT optimization (high level); Practical implication: performance varies, warm-up/optimization. referenceAnswers.text: Network latency is the delay in the transmission of data packets, while jitter is the variation in latency over time. Both latency and jitter can negatively impact real-time applications by causing delays, poor call quality, and synchronization issues.
keyPoints: Answer directly: JS is executed by an engine that compiles/JITs internally
Explain interpreted vs compiled as a spectrum in modern engines
Mention parse -> bytecode -> JIT optimization (high level)
Practical implication: performance varies, warm-up/optimization

open_questions.title: MPLS (Multiprotocol Label Switching), and how
open_questions.description: What is MPLS (Multiprotocol Label Switching), and how does it enhance the efficiency of packet forwarding in IP networks?

referenceAnswers.text: MPLS is a protocol used for high-performance packet forwarding in IP networks. It assigns labels to packets, allowing routers to make forwarding decisions based on labels rather than complex IP header lookups. MPLS enhances network efficiency, scalability, and quality of service (QoS).

Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concepts of DNS load balancing

Answer the question: "Explain the concepts of DNS load balancing and anycast, and how they can improve the availability and performance of internet services.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: DNS load balancing distributes incoming DNS queries across multiple server instances to distribute the load and improve service availability and responsiveness. Anycast is a routing technique where the same IP address is advertised from multiple locations, allowing traffic to be directed to the nearest server. Both techniques enhance service availability and performance.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: VLAN trunking is a technique that allows multiple VLANs to share a single network link (usually between switches). It adds a VLAN tag to Ethernet frames to identify which VLAN the frame belongs to, enabling traffic from different VLANs to coexist on the same physical link.

Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Q-in-Q is a technique that adds an additional VLAN tag to Ethernet frames. It's used in network virtualization and provider networks to encapsulate customer VLANs within service provider VLANs, enabling isolation and segmentation of customer traffic.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of HSRP (Hot Standby
open_questions.description: What is the purpose of HSRP (Hot Standby Router Protocol) and VRRP (Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol), and how do they enhance network reliability?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the purpose of HSRP (Hot Standby Router Protocol) and VRRP (Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol), and how do they enhance network reliability?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.

referenceAnswers.text: HSRP and VRRP are protocols used to provide high availability and redundancy in networks by allowing multiple routers to share a virtual IP address. If one router fails, another can take over, ensuring uninterrupted network connectivity.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice
